data.meta_description: Singer Jon Bon Jovi, actor Edward Norton and entrepreneur Jimmy Wales will receive the 2015 Common Wealth Awards of Distinguished Service.
data.text:
An actor and musician with ties to the Mid-Atlantic region and the man who founded Wikipedia will receive the 2015 Common Wealth Awards of Distinguished Service.

Singer Jon Bon Jovi, actor Edward Norton and entrepreneur Jimmy Wales are being recognized as people who have made lasting contributions to modern culture through professional and personal efforts. They will be honored at an April 25 awards ceremony at the Hotel du Pont in Wilmington, where each will be presented with a check for $75,000.

Bon Jovi grew up in New Jersey and has ties to Philadelphia, and Norton grew up in Baltimore. They were cited for public service. Wales was cited for his contributions to mass communications.

"The 2015 Common Wealth Award honorees are distinguished achievers in their respective fields who share a broader commitment to global social responsibility," Nicholas M. Marsini Jr. regional president for PNC Bank, Delaware said in a press release.

The awards were founded in 1979 through the will of Ralph Hayes, a businessman and philanthropist who served on the board of PNC Bank. The bank now oversees the awards, which have given more than $6 million to 192 honorees in the fields of dramatic arts, literature, science, invention, mass communications, public service, government and sociology.

The 2015 winners join the ranks of celebrities such as Archbishop Desmond Tutu, statesman Henry Kissinger, former Secretary of State Colin Powell, H.M. Queen Noor of Jordan; dance legend Mikhail Baryshnikov, authors Gabriel Garcia Marquez and Toni Morrison and Hollywood icons Sidney Poitier and Meryl Streep.

Here's more about the winners:

• Jon Bon Jovi, lead singer of Grammy Award-winning rock band and humanitarian

Born in Perth Amboy, New Jersey, and raised in Garden State, Bon Jovi is a local favorite musician whose band Bon Jovi has sold more than 130 million albums and performed more than 2,900 concerts in over 50 countries for more than 37.5 million fans. His last album debuted at No. 1 around the world and his tour that year ended 2013 as the No. 1 tour. He also owns the Philadelphia Soul of the Arena Football League.

Bon Jovi has also raised millions for charitable causes that focus on the community and self-reliance. He is the chairman of the Jon Bon Jovi Soul Foundation, a non-profit dedicated to bringing about positive change and helping people "one SOUL at a time." It focuses on The foundation runs the JBJ Soul Kitchen in Red Bank, New Jersey. It also helped with recovery efforts after Hurricane Sandy in 2012.

Jon Bon Jovi has worked on behalf of Special Olympics, the American Red Cross, the Elizabeth Glaser Pediatrics Foundation, Habitat for Humanity, Covenant House, Project H.O.M.E and others.

• Edward Norton, award-winning actor, screenwriter, director, produce, philanthropist and social and environmental activist.

Norton was born in Boston, Massachusetts, but raised in Columbia, Maryland. He's best known as an actor who has been nominated for three Academy Awards, for "Primal Fear," "American History X" and "Birdman" and won a Golden Globe along with numerous other awards for his performances. He's directed seven films, including the documentary "By The People: The Election of Barack Obama." This summer, HBO will film "Lewis and Clark," a six-part miniseries that Norton co-wrote and is producing.

Out of the spotlight he actively supports several causes. Norton serves on the Board of Trustees of Enterprise Community Partners, which works to move families out of poverty and transform low-income communities through the development of affordable housing and social service networks. Enterprise was created by Norton's grandfather, James Rouse, a developer and philanthropist. Norton also works with the Peacemakers Fund at Yale University, where he earned a degree in history. He contributed $100,000 to that fund to help provide travel-study grants for Yale undergraduates to study the people, languages and cultures of the Middle East and Central Asia.

In 2008, Norton was appointed by President Obama to his committee for the Arts and Humanities. And in 2010 Norton was appointed the first United Nations Goodwill Ambassador for Biodiversity by UN Secretary General Ban.

Norton and three partners founded the company CrowdRise, a web platform on which individuals, organizations and companies can crowdfund for charities and non-profits. It also allows people to raise assistance for other individuals in need directly to support medical or education costs or recovery from a crisis. It was named by Barron's as one of the "25 Most Important New Ideas in Philanthropy."

• Jimmy Wales, founder of Wikipedia, for Mass Communications.

Jimmy Donal Wales is a U.S. Internet entrepreneur, wiki pioneer and technology visionary, who is best known as the Founder of Wikipedia and the Wikimedia Foundation. Wikipedia bgan in March 200 when Wales started Nupedia ("the free encyclopedia"), which was characterized by an extensive peer-review process designed to make its articles of a quality comparable to that of professional encyclopedias. With the addition of wikis (web pages designed to enable anyone who accesses it to contribute or modify content), the project was dubbed "Wikipedia." Its rapid growth quickly overshadowed.

"Imagine a world in which every single person on the planet is given free access to the sum of all human knowledge. That's what we're doing," Wales said in 2004. His work with Wikipedia, which has become the world's largest encyclopedia, led to Time magazine naming him one of its "100 Most Influential People," in 2006 and the World Economic Forum recognized Wales as one of the "Young Global Leaders" of 2007.

In 2003, Wales founded the Wikimedia Foundation, a nonprofit charitable organization dedicated to encouraging the growth, development and distribution of free, multilingual content, and to providing the full content of these wiki-based projects to the public free of charge. In 2004, Wales co-founded the for-profit company Wikia Inc. Wikia is a wiki farm – a collection of individual wikis on different subjects, all hosted on the same website.

Wales is a Fellow of the Berkman Center for Internet & Society at Harvard Law School. He serves on the Board of Directors of Socialtext, a provider of wiki technology to businesses and the nonprofit organization Creative Commons.

A native of Huntsville, Ala., Wales received his bachelor's degree in finance from Auburn University and started with the Ph.D. finance program at the University of Alabama, where he left with a Master's. After that, he took courses offered in the Ph.D. finance program at Indiana University. He taught at both universities during his postgraduate studies, but did not write the doctoral dissertation required to earn a Ph.D.
